change.item: PUBLIC "-//University of California, Los Angeles::Library::Dept. of Special Collections//TEXT (US::CLU-SC::175::Kenneth Rexroth Papers)//EN" "rexro175.sgm" converted from EAD 1.0 to 2002 by v1to02.cdl.xsl (2004-09-16).

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.abstract: Kenneth Rexroth (1905-1982) was an author, critic, poet, teacher, translator and active member of San Francisco's cultural, political, and poetry scenes from the 1930s through the 1960s. The collection consists of correspondence, manuscripts, and ephemera by and about Rexroth, and members of his circle.

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: University of California, Los Angeles. Library Special Collections.

did.physloc: Stored off-site at SRLF. Advance notice is required for access to the collection. Please contact the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk for paging information.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: COLLECTION STORED OFF-SITE AT SRLF: Open for research. Advance notice required for access. Contact the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk for paging information.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical object belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. Literary rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

acqinfo.head: Provenance/Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift from Joseph S. Handler (Series 2, the Esther Handler papers), 2004.

processinfo.head: Processing Information:
processinfo.p: Initial processing of the collection was completed in 1965. In preparation for shipment to SRLF, Simon Elliott and Lilace Hatayama created a brief list of post-1965 additions to the collection in 1990. Eric Gudas fully reprocessed the manuscripts and Handler series with assistance from Laurel McPhee in 2004-2005; all other series were processed by Laurel McPhee with assistance from CFPRT staff in 2005.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Kenneth Rexroth Papers (Collection 175). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Born December 22, 1905 in South Bend, Indiana; campaigned for many radical groups, particularly the Wobblies (Industrial Workers of the World), and espoused eroticism and general anarchy; influenced by poet William Carlos Williams and the Second Chicago Renaissance; founded San Francisco Poetry Center with Lawrence Ferlinghetti and Allen Ginsberg; although his Bohemian lifestyle was emulated by Beats, he did not like the movement for its artistic excess and lack of rigor; noted as an accomplished painter with one-man shows throughout the world; translated poems from the Chinese and Japanese languages; died June 6, 1982 in Montecito, California.

bioghist.head: Expanded Biographical Narrative
bioghist.p: Kenneth Rexroth (22 Dec. 1905- 6 June 1982) was born in Southwest Indiana. His family lived in various Midwestern cities until he was orphaned in 1919, and moved in with an aunt in Chicago. Rexroth pursued a vigorous self-education while working odd jobs, backpacking across the country, and writing poetry; his early work was strongly influenced by Chicago's Second Renaissance. He married Andrée Schafer in 1927, and the couple moved to San Francisco. During the early 1930s, Rexroth became involved in the Communist party's John Reed Clubs. During this time he developed friendships with other leftist poets. In the mid-1930s, Rexroth participated in the Federal Writers' Project, and published some of his poetry in journals and little magazines. His lifelong friendship with prominent New Directions publisher James Laughlin was established at this time.

In 1938 Rexroth shifted his Communist-based political ideologies to an ecologically informed pacifism. He married Marie Kass following his first wife's death in 1940, and registered as a conscientious objector during World War II. Rexroth established a philosophy club and hosted discussion salons that attracted other West coast intellectuals and poets, and became known as the father of the Beat generation.

Rexroth received a Guggenheim fellowship in 1948 and traveled extensively across Europe and the United States. He fathered his two daughters, Katharine and Mary, by philosophy student Marthe Larsen. In addition to his weekly radio show and writings, Rexroth began to read poetry with live jazz accompaniment at popular performances. After Kass divorced him in 1955, Rexroth wed Larsen in 1958; they divorced in 1961.

In the 1960s Rexroth supported both civil rights struggles and the anti-war movement. Disassociating himself from his radical past and cultural affiliation with Beatniks and Bohemians, Rexroth became more aligned with the mainstream media and was a regular essayist for the Saturday Review and San Francisco Examiner. Rexroth received a National Institute of Arts and Letters award in 1964. He became a lecturer at the University of California, Santa Barbara (1968-1974), where he taught popular writing courses. His later poems were greatly influenced by Eastern philosophy and the work of Japanese and Chinese poets; he also became known for his poetry translations. In 1974 and 1975, Rexroth won a Fulbright to Japan and a Copernicus Award for lifetime achievement. He married his fourth wife, Carol Tinker, in 1974. He died in Santa Barbara in 1982.

Rexroth's poetry publications include: In What Hour (1940), The Phoenix and the Tortoise (1944), The Signature of All Things (1949), In Defense of the Earth (1956), Natural Numbers (1963), Elastic Retort (1973), New Poems (1974), and Flower Wreath Hill (1991). His translations include 100 Poems from the Chinese (1956), 100 Poems from the Japanese (1964), Pierre Reverdy, Selected Poems (1969), Love and the Turning Year (1970), Orchid Boat (1972), 100 Poems from the French (1972), and 100 More Poems from the Japanese (1976).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of original correspondence, manuscripts, and assorted printed materials that document Rexroth's writing, interests, and activities. Of particular note is the voluminous personal correspondence between Rexroth and close friends and family members, in addition to correspondence from major writers, poets and cultural figures, including: Ansel Adams, Homero Ardijis, Robert Bly, John Cicardi, Lawrence Ferlinghetti, Morgan Gibson, Allen Ginsberg, James Laughlin, Denise Levertov, Gerard Malanga, Henry Miller, Kenneth Patchen, Edouard Roditi, William Carlos Williams, Edward Weston, and George Woodcock. The collection also includes single letters from prominent people such as Pearl S. Buck, James P. Cooney, Jack Kerouac, Ezra Pound, Man Ray, and Isaac B. Singer, among others. The manuscript series contains Rexroth's typescripts and handwritten works across several genres, including poetry, prose, translations, reviews, and his work for the Federal Writers' Project. Other series include extensive ephemera documenting the San Francisco scene, such as anti-Vietnam fliers, posters announcing readings, and event invitations; selected audio recordings of Rexroth's jazz readings and radio series; articles and clippings about Rexroth and his circle; little magazines; and Rexroth's teaching and lecture files.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
Correspondence, 1853-1979 (bulk 1950-1975) (39 boxes), subseries A-B as follows:
A-Z, 1853-1979 (bulk 1950-1975) (35 boxes).
Cards, 1954-1975 (4 boxes).
Esther Handler papers, 1957-1986 (2 boxes), subseries A-B as follows:
Correspondence, 1958-1986 (1 box).
Miscellaneous, 1957-1986 (1 box).
Manuscripts by Rexroth, 1922-1976 (35 boxes), subseries A-F as follows:
Book reviews, 1937-1968 (1 box).
Federal Writers Project, 1936-1939 (1 box).
Notebooks, ca. 1935-1950 (0.5 box).
Poetry and verse, 1922-1967 (9.5 boxes).
Prose, 1935-1976 (18 boxes).
Translations, 1952-1974 (5 boxes).
Manuscripts by others, 1936-1975 (18.5 boxes), subseries A-B as follows:
A-Z, 1936-1975 (17.5 boxes).
Lonergan Conference papers, 1970 (1 box).
Miscellaneous, 1925-1974 (15.5 boxes), subseries A-F as follows:
Artwork, 1941-1969 (1 folder).
Audio recordings, 1952-1966 (6 boxes).
Finances and calendars, 1947-1970 (5 boxes).
Kenneth Rexroth Books, 1940- 1957 (1 box).
Photographs, 1925-1958 (1 folder).
Travel, 1948-1974 (3.5 boxes).
Printed material, 1936-1976 (36 boxes), subseries A-F as follows:
Articles and essays, 1946-1975 (3.5 boxes).
Clippings and reviews, 1936-1975 (3 boxes).
Ephemera, 1940-1974 (10 boxes).
Little magazines, 1936-1976 (8 boxes).
Newspapers, 1938-1975 (5 boxes).
Periodicals and newsletters, 1944-1975 (6.5 boxes).
Teaching, 1953-1974 (9 boxes), subseries A-C as follows:
Lectures, 1953-1974 (2 boxes).
San Francisco State College, 1957-1966 (1 box).
UC Santa Barbara, 1968-1974 (6 box).

controlaccess.head: Indexing Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the library's online public access catalog.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Periodical articles by Rexroth are in the Little Mag Collection (1000). Available at Library Special Collections, UCLA.

Butler, Jerry & Eager, Brenda Lee. The love we have. Chicago, Illinois: Phonogram Incorporated, 1973. 1 album (2 s.) 12 in. 33 1/3 rpm.
Two poems on the inside jacket cover are from Kenneth Rexroth's 100 poems from the Japanese. 10.

scopecontent.p: Personal and professional correspondence. Additional letters to Rexroth may also be found as enclosures with manuscripts (see Series 4), or in his teaching and lecture files (see Series 7).

Arranged in Subseries A-B as follows:
A. A-Z, 1853-1979 (bulk 1950-1975) (35 boxes).
B. Cards, 1954-1975 (4 boxes).

Personal and professional correspondence from various people to Kenneth Rexroth, including critics, editors, fans, poets, publishers and writers. Arranged alphabetically by surname of the correspondent, where possible. Letters from unidentified sources have been placed in folders labled "Unidentified" and filed within the "U's." For correspondence from poets regarding Rexroth's New British Poets anothology, search for the names of individual poets in this series, in addition to reviewing the New British Poets manuscript found in Subseries 3D.

did.unittitle: Adams, Leonie; Bogan, Louise; Deutsch, Babette.

scopecontent.p: Typescript of omnibus review of books by Adams, Bogan, and Deutsch with handwritten annotations, plus clippings of photographs appearing with the published column; typescript of review of Bogan's Selected Criticism.
Carbon typescript entitled "Advertisers anonymous; that $2.95 magazine." Published in The Nation, Oct. 29, 1955; v. 181, no. 18, pp. 358-9.
Carbon typescript of Baudelaire, A Self-Portrait: Selected Letters, published in The Nation, v. 185, no. 33, July 20, 1957.
Typescript review of The Light Around the Body, and A Poetry Reading Against the Vietnam War.
Carbon typescript of review of Buber's Hasidism and Modern Man.
Typescript review of the University of Chicago's series.

Typescript review of Zen and the Notebooks of Samuel Taylor Coleridge, ed. Kathleen Coburn (written for the Chicago Review, but never published), and James Baken's The Sacred River: Coleridge's Theory of Imagination.
Typescript review of special issue on myths and mythmaking.
Typescript and carbon review of Still Rebels, Still Yankees, annotated.

Typescript review of Balthazar, published in The Nation, v. 187, no. 116, Sept. 6, 1958. Galleys of review for The Black Book, published in The Griffin, Sept. 1960, annotated by Tom Lowry, managing editor.
Typescript review of The Forgotten Language, annotated; note to Robert Hatch on leaf 3.
Handwritten review of The Letters of Edward Gibbon, ed. J.E. Norton, published in The Nation, v. 182, no. 556, June 30, 1956.

did.unittitle: Gruen, Victor and David R. Hunter.

scopecontent.p: Typescript reviews of The Heart of our Cities by Gruen, and The Slums by Hunter; plus a letter about the review from R.B. Silvers at New York Review of Books.
Typescript review of Thomas Mann, published in the New Republic, Aug. 20, 1951.
Typescript review of The Horn, published in Saturday Review of Literature, v. 41, no. 11, Aug.2, 1958.
Typescript review of Society: Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow, ed. by MacKenzie, published in New Masses, New York (v. 24, no. 4, July 20, 1937), pp. 24-25.
Typescript review of The Peasant of the Garonne.
Typescript review of Men Against the State.
Typescript review of The Parkman Reader, ed. by Samuel Eliot Morison, published in The Nation, v. 181, no. 14, July 2, 1955.
Typescript reviews of Art and Society and Collected Poems, published in the New York Times, June 17, 1951, p. 5; plus typescript of Rexroth's introduction to Read's The Green Child.
Typescript review of Body of Waking, annotated; plus clipping of published review from the New York Times Book Review, October 19, 1958.
Typescript review of books about magic, annotated.
Typescript review of Singer's Gimpel the Fool, and other stories.
Typescript review of books about urbanism.
Typescript review of The Complete Letters of Vincent Van Gogh, annotated.
Typescript review of Poems by Wang Wei (translated by Chang Yin-nan and Leavis C. Walmsley), annotated. Note at bottom of page reads "To Francis Brown, New York Times Book Review."
Typescript reviews of The Desert Music, plus 1 leaf of commentary on Williams "written for San Francisco appearance at Poetry Center."
Typescript review of The Collected Plays of W.B. Yeats.
Typescript review of Yu-lan's History of Chinese Philosophy, annotated.
Manuscripts written while Rexroth was an employee of the Federal Writers' Project for the U.S. Works Progress (later Work Projects) Administration (WPA), which operated from 1936-1940.
Original pencil and ink illustrations, and photostat copies. Includes a letter referring to the drawings from Franz Brandt, Supervisor, de Young Museum Project, N.Y.U.
Typescripts on Mt. Shasta, The National Tour (state line to Sacramento), the South fork of the Kings River, Mineral King, and Sequoia.

Remember now there were others before this. Gentlemen, I address you publicly. Shall ask no more (from The Crisis). Short holograph note in Rexroth's hand laid in.

scopecontent.p: Annotated typescripts, first published by Pym-Randall Press. Includes additional poems and translations.
Handwritten and typescript versions; plus letter from Rexroth to his wife, Marthe, regarding his intent to seek publication. For oversize galley proofs with annotations, see box 158.

did.unittitle: In Defense of the Earth--Annotated typescripts.

scopecontent.p: Incomplete, corrected, and master mss. First published in Sausalito by the Golden Goose Press, 1953; master version from later publication by New Directions, New York, 1956.

did.unittitle: In Defense of the Earth--Galley proofs.
In Defense of the Earth / Homestead Called Damascus / 30 Spanish Poems.

scopecontent.p: Typescript, in mixed order and with some duplication. First published in New York by Macmillan, 1940.

did.unittitle: Iphegenia at Aulis: a dance play.

scopecontent.p: Annotated typescript of poem, and Greek translation.

did.unittitle: Love is an Art of Time.

scopecontent.p: Several long poems in mixed order and various stages of development; notes, possibly for poems or essays, also in mixed order, etc.; numerous short poems, most untitled, with miscellaneous notations. Many of the mss. appear incomplete, and the leaves have been filled on both sides. Typewritten and handwritten sheets, with corrections.
Handwritten poems. First published as part of In Defense of the Earth, by the Golden Goose Press in Sausalito, 1953.
Typescript. First published in New York by New Directions, 1963.
Folder labeled "Old Poems" containing approximately 200 annotated typescripts and handwritten poems.
Typescript of ballet choreography; letter from James Laughlin.
Handwritten and typescript versions. Included in Steuben Glass interpretation of poetry, Poetry in Crystal, 1962.
Annotated typescripts and notes. First published in Norfolk, Conn., by New Directions, 1944. Includes most of the poems in the final version, in mixed order. First leaf inscribed, "Marie's copy."
Folders of poetry. Includes work from In What Hour, and a version of the essay The Function of the Poet in Society, plus unpublished pieces.
Annotated typescript, plus galley proofs. Many of the poems have notes by Rexroth about previous publication. First published in New York by New Directions, 1950.

did.unittitle: Sky Sea Birds Trees Earth House Beasts Flowers.

scopecontent.p: Typescript; includes Rexroth's translations of two poems by Jules Supervielle.

did.unittitle: The Spark in the Tinder of Knowing.
The Thin Edge of Your Pride.

scopecontent.p: Arranged alphabetically, where possible, by the given title of the manuscript or published work, with the exception of magazine articles. "Miscellaneous" folders contain manuscripts that were filed together by Rexroth in unlabeled folders, and the original order was preserved at the time of processing.
Typescript essay for NY Times Book Review.
Annotated typescripts and selections. See box 158 for oversize galley proofs.

did.unittitle: American Poetry in the Twentieth Century.

scopecontent.p: Annotated typescript; see box 158 for oversize galley proofs.

did.unittitle: American Poetry in the Twentieth Century.
The Arts In An Age of Anxiety.

scopecontent.p: Carbon typescripts with handwritten annotations. As returned from the publisher, New Directions, in New York.
Handwritten and typescript versions of essay.

did.unittitle: An Autobiographical Novel--Rough draft off final tapes.

scopecontent.p: Photocopied typescript. Chapters 1-25. See box 158 for an annotated galley proof.
Includes letters of criticism from Double Day editors.
Draft of introduction and supplementary material.
Photocopies of a three-page autobiographical statement.

did.unittitle: BBC Lectures on the Beat Generation.

scopecontent.p: Drafts and correspondence related to a lecture series.
Handwritten and typescript essay on Blin's version of Samuel Beckett's Godot.
Typescripts, bound. Incomplete. Essays appear to be different versions of other essays in the collection.

did.unittitle: Communalism: Its Origins to the Twentieth Century.

scopecontent.p: Handwritten and typescript essays from a folder labeled "Drafts of magazine articles."
Drafts and typescript essays from a folder labeled "1968".
Typescripts and bibliography for article on literature.
Typescripts removed from a binder with the same title.
Typescript of Rexroth's keynote address; correspondence and ephemera.
Typescript essays in a folder by the same title (mostly from Assays and Bird in the Bush).

did.unittitle: How Poets Make A Living, If Any.

scopecontent.p: Drafts, clipping of published article, and related questionnaire.

did.unittitle: The Influence of French Poetry on American.

scopecontent.p: Annotated typescript, "The neglected Henry Miller." First published in The Nation, v. 181, no. 19, Nov. 5, 1955, pp. 385-7. Published later as the introduction to Miller's Nights of Love and Laughter in paperback form by Signet.
Annotated typescripts, not known if published. Notation at top of first leaf reads: "to Selected Writings of Kenneth Patchen."
Annotated typescript for The Holy Kabbala.

did.unittitle: Is There a Crisis of Public Morals? Of Private?.

scopecontent.p: Assorted essays on Japan and Japanese literature.

did.unittitle: Japanese Show, San Francisco DeYoung Museum.

scopecontent.p: Annotated typescript, in a hand other than Rexroth's.
Typescript of letter to George Woodcock, published as "Letter from America" in Now, London, v. 7 (Feb.-Mar.).

did.unittitle: Little Anthology of Little Magazine Poets.

scopecontent.p: Originally compiled for the New Republic, but not known if published. Includes poems by Denise Levertov, Leslie Woolf Hedley, Scott Greer, Cid Corman, Robert Duncan, Frederick Eckman, Robert Creeley, Richard Wirtz Emerson, Chris Bjerknes, Gill Orlovitz, Charles Olsen, Philip Lamantia, and commentary by Rexroth. Handwritten introduction; complete. typescript and correspondence.
Assorted essays and articles for a variety of publishers.
Typescripts of essays in cardboard binder.

did.unittitle: Morals, Ethics, Religion, Ideology, the Poet, Poetry.

scopecontent.p: Collection of individual manuscripts sent to Rexroth for inclusion in his anthology by the poets whose work he requested. Leaves are in mixed order with poems heavily annotated by the authors and in Rexroth's hand. Includes introduction.

scopecontent.p: Typescript of article on William Everson.

The Other World: Essays from the Alternative Society.

scopecontent.p: Typescript of lecture notes: general remarks, Chinese poetry, and folk songs and ballads.
Typewritten and handwritten notes for a KPIX 5 TV program, "Poverty: Crisis in the Affluent Society."

scopecontent.p: Typescript of program notes for performance at Lincoln Center; supporting documents.

scopecontent.p: Typescripts and notes. Includes lists of possible selections and outline for essay. Published by New Directions in New York, 1947.

scopecontent.p: Arranged alphabetically, where possible, by the given title of the manuscript or published work.

scopecontent.p: Typescript of French and English verse. Lacking two poems which appear in the published version. Published in San Francisco by the Peregrine Press, 1952.

did.unittitle: One Hundred Poems from the Chinese.

scopecontent.p: Annotated typescripts and galley proofs. First published in New York by New Directions, 1956.

did.unittitle: One Hundred Poems from the French.

scopecontent.p: Translations from 20th century French poets, intended for publication by Jargon Press, but not published. Includes mixed typescripts and handwritten drafts for 1955 edition, and photocopied typescript of 1971 edition.

did.unittitle: One Hundred Poems from the Japanese.

scopecontent.p: Assorted packets of typescripts and handwritten MSS of Japanese poems (including Katue Kitsasono) and English translations; Rexroth's introduction. Includes galley proofs.
Annotated typescripts and handwritten notes, plus a folder entitled "Texts Chinese Women Ling Chung," with handwritten Chinese texts and translations. See box 158 for annotated galleys.
Rexroth translations set to music by Betty Beath.

Typescript, and two Rexroth poems translated into Greek. Includes an introduction by Rexroth. Published in Ann Arbor, Michigan, by the University of Michigan Press, 1962. See box 158 for annotated galleys.

did.unittitle: Thirty Spanish Poems of Love and Exile.

scopecontent.p: Handwritten draft. First published in San Francisco by the City Lights Pocket Bookshop, 1956 (Pocket Series no. 2).
Manuscripts by others sent to Kenneth Rexroth, typically for comments, feedback and review.

Arranged in Subseries A-B as follows:
A. A-Z, 1936-1975 (17.5 boxes).
B. Lonergan Conference papers, 1970 (1 box).
Subseries 4A consists largely of poetry manuscripts submitted to Rexroth for review. Arranged alphabetically by the surname of the author; unidentified manuscripts may be found under "U."
Short Change; Blue Blue Blue Suede Shoes
Selections from Amerika Amerikka Amerikkka, translated with a letter by David Smith
Partial translation of Iliad (Texas Quarterly, v. 2 no. 4); translation of Aristophanes' The Birds

"Copulas on the Death of Merton", translated by Mireya James-Freyre and Kenneth Rexroth

Review of Sherston's Progress by Siegfried Sassoon

"Words Coherent Incoherent Crazy by Day Crying by Night"; letter

Assorted poems including: "The Great Brook Book"; "I Am Flying Around To Find Me/Morgan's Body Morning"; and "Crystal Sunlake"
"Excerpts from The Hierarchy of Heaven and Earth"
Assorted writings, and two black and white photographic portraits

"Prometheus: A Play in Two Acts and Six Scenes"
Poem ("We who have sensed the futility.")

Two untitled groups of poems; two letters

"In California: Sunday Sun", "The Light of Low Sunday & the Wind"; "Dirge for the Bathing Beaches"

Poems; transcript of 3/16/57 interview with Lipton on CBS TV with attached photograph of Lipton; typescript of "Rainbow at Midnight"
"While My Anger Holds"; "The Poetry Radar"; "One Poem One Riddle One Dream One Dance"
Poems and stories; letter; newspaper clipping
Galleys of Milosz's "Selected Poems", with introduction by Rexroth

".And See If It'll Grow Lilies"; "Letter to Kenneth Rexroth"; "Meditation on Books"

Two Fragments from a "Tune River Anthology"

Six folders of unidentified manuscripts, consisting largely of poetry.

Lengthy manuscript of poems; cover letter

Assorted poems and a music score
Copies of essays submitted by various authors for the First International Lonergan Conference. Rexroth served on the conference committee.

scopecontent.p: Letter to Kenneth Rexroth; assorted essays

did.unittitle: First International Lonergan Conference papers (folders 2-6 of 7).
First International Lonergan Conference papers (folder 7 of 7).

scopecontent.p:
Arranged in Subseries A-F as follows:
A. Artwork, 1941-1969 (1 folder).
B. Audio recordings, 1952-1966 (6 boxes).
C. Finances and calendars, 1947-1970 (5 boxes).
D. Kenneth Rexroth Books, 1940-1957 (1 box).
E. Photographs, 1925-1958 (1 folder).
F. Travel, 1948-1974 (3.5 boxes).
Original sketches and artwork. See box 159 for an original pastel by Kenneth Rexroth (gift of Joseph Handler).

Includes original watercolors, drawings, and caricatures of Rexroth and other subjects. Artists include Barney Howell and Manuel Caipo. See box 159 for an oversize caricature of Rexroth as a Communist, and an original pastel by Rexroth of a fish in a waterfall.

Tape reels and recordings primarily consisting of lectures, poetry readings, programs, and seminars by Rexroth and others. Preservation reformatting was recommended during the 2005 reprocessing; materials are restricted until further notice. Please inquire in advance for availability.
Includes rehearsal for a festival and recording by Lionel Haupton.

did.unittitle: Jazz Poetry--Rexroth and the Dick Mills Quintet.
Jazz poetry--Rexroth and Ferlinghetti at the Cellar.
MacDiarmid, Hugh--A Drunk Man Looks at the Thistle.

scopecontent.p: Includes readings by Don Gordon, Naomi Replansky, and Thomas McGrath.

did.unittitle: Rexroth--"Delay and commercialization of the image of revolt" (lecture).

scopecontent.p: Includes recordings of Original Narratives of Early American History, and a reading at Reed College.

did.unittitle: Rexroth--"An outsider looks at the awakening in the church" (lecture).
University of Chicago Poets Round Table and unidentified recordings.

scopecontent.p: Personal calendars and records of Rexroth family finances, including income tax forms and receipts for expenses. Arranged chronologically.

Bills, correspondence and invoices from Kenneth Rexroth's San Francisco book shop, removed from a binder labeled "Kenneth Rexroth Books." Additional correspondence with publishers may be found in Series 1.
Correspondence to Monse Chicago, INC. regarding Fred Goudy's Trajan Title type face
Check, invoices, and letter from D. Jonathan Grossman
Assorted business cards, checks, postcards, book dealers and "wanted lists"
Assorted black and white photographs of Kenneth Rexroth, his family, and members of his circle (such as Henry Miller), mostly unlabeled.

Correspondence, ephemera and maps from Rexroth's travels. The Japan folders include correspondence related to the Japanese P.E.N. Society, international conferences, and fellowship and living arrangements.
Includes a list of European contacts.
Includes poems from a joint reading by Kenneth Rexroth and Shuntaro Tanikawa.

Arranged in Subseries A-F as follows:
A. Articles and essays, 1946-1975 (3.5 boxes).
B. Clippings and reviews, 1936-1975 (3 boxes).
C. Ephemera, 1940-1974 (10 boxes).
D. Little magazines, 1936-1976 (8 boxes).
E. Newspapers, 1938-1975 (5 boxes).
F. Periodicals and newsletters, 1944-1975 (6.5 boxes).

Copies and reprints of published articles and essays by Rexroth and others. Arranged alphabetically by the surname of the author. Rexroth's articles, consisting largely of clippings from published newspaper columns, are further arranged into alphabetical files by the title of the piece. For a scrapbook of clippings of Rexroth's "Classics Revisited" column, see box 157.
"An experimental college model"; NDEA foreign language institute programs
"Some personality correlates of independence of judgment"
Report: "Supplement to the San Francisco city-state joint freeway study on the Panhandle and Golden Gate freeways "
"Reapportionment of the state legislature"; and "Division of California" by Robert N Bulla (1907)
"Posterity is just around the corner--or is it?"
"The economic situation of the poet: a professional problem?"
"The presence of reality: the poetry of Kenneth Rexroth"
Proposals presented to the 1966 meeting of the Association for Recorded Sound Collections held at Washington, D.C., USA
"Evolutionary socialism, syndicalism, guild socialism and anarchism"
"Vaino Linna and Veijo Meri, two aspects of war"
"Population dynamics of intestinal epithelia in the rat two months after partial resection of the ileum"
"The care and feeding of the arts"
Resignation statement by Miriam and Charles Lindstrom.
"The emergence of the persona in the poetry of Neruda"
"Relatively yours" (essay in response to Rexroth's comments on black vs white)
"The Rolf Method of postural release and integration"
"Report on the rehabilitation and modernization of San Francisco's War Memorial Cultural Center"
Assorted reprints of articles and essays.
"The making of Jews, or The inquisition in Portugal"
"Structural integration: gravity, an unexplored factor in a more human use of human beings"
"The year's developments in the arts and sciences"
Assorted poems and an essay introduction.
"Modes of being and time in the world of Godot"
"Will the works of abstract art be the dominating factor in the culture of the future?"
"A concluding lecture in American economic history"
"Das Kapital one hundred years later"; "The Russian intelligentsia"

Clippings on a variety of subjects, including reviews of Rexroth's work, courtesy of his clipping service. Arranged by original subject filing titles, with the exception of: reviews, which are further arranged by the title of the reviewed work; clippings about Rexroth, which have been further arranged in a chronological order. For two scrapbooks with additional clippings of reviews, see box 60.
Copies of clippings related to the San Francisco paper.
Clipping features a photo of Gary Snyder.
Articles about the obscenity trial for Ginsberg's "Howl" and a photocopy of the original mimeograph. The original has been removed and added to the Bound Manuscripts collection, 170/736 .
Miscellaneous newspapers and clippings with no mention of Rexroth.

did.unittitle: Reviews--Collected Longer Poems of Kenneth Rexroth.
Reviews--Collected Shorter Poems of Kenneth Rexroth.
Reviews--Fourteen Poems by O.V. De L. Miolsz.
Reviews--30 Spanish Poems of Love and Exile.

scopecontent.p: Assorted newspaper and magazine clippings that mention of Rexroth.

Ephemeral materials from a variety of sources, particularly events, primarily from San Francisco in the 1960s. Arranged alphabetically by file title, which is either the creator name or the general topic of the contents. See box 159 for oversize materials such as publicity posters announcing readings by Rexroth, Ferlinghetti, Ginsberg, Snyder, and others.

did.unittitle: Ad Hoc Committee on the Triple Revolution.

Who's Who certificate; humorous certificate signed by John Ciardi.

Featuring Carlos Chavez and Kenneth Rexroth.
Report to the governor; artists' protest of the Vietnam conflict; the palace of fine arts.

Poems of Po Chu-I, translated by Frank W. Price.
Rules for Being Dressed to Kill (broadside, Denver: Absynthe House).
Booklet of poetry entitled First Crescent.
Publicity materials stapled together, including an interview with Michelle Nichols.
Illustrated booklet of French poetry entitled Noel Otomi.
The Plague in Saigon (Polemic Publication no. 1, San Francisco: Protest Press).

Announcements and ephemera related to conferences and local events, primarily dramatic productions, exhibitions, gatherings, and readings. See box 159 for publicity posters for readings by Rexroth, Snyder, Ferlinghetti, Ginsberg, and others.
Announcements and ephemera related to conferences and local events, primarily dramatic productions, exhibitions, gatherings, and readings.
Prospectuses, catalogs, cards and announcements from fine printers, including Red Hill Press, Cranium Press, Hoyem, etc.

scopecontent.p: Assorted programs. For additional German matierals, see Series 5, Subseries 5F (Travel).
A Portfolio of Drawings of Elkhart and Vicinity.

Blink (illustrated poem, New York: Buffalo Press).
Clippings about hippies and a printed letter from Father Harris, pastor of the All Saint's Haight Ashbury parish.
Printed material about housing developments in Islamabad, Baghdad, and Philadelphia.

scopecontent.p: Assorted open letters, fliers, and articles about the Santa Barbara riots.

The Changeling (Malpelo broadside one, copy d/a-z), signed by the author.

Letter-press version of single poem, Komos, signed by the author; flier.

Assorted printed materials, including a French songbook for Edith Paif's "La vie en rose", a Credo for Librarians, a list of interview questions (presumably for Rexroth) and small booklets by anonymous authors.
Political pamphlet, "Pyramiding Echelons of Tens: A Plan for a Cooperative Economic Democracy and a Party to Promote the Plan" (Iowa: U.S. Farm News).
Booklet of poems entitled, The Fat Wing Lung Company Poems.

Assorted prospectuses for authors, periodicals, and books.

Assorted print advertising material for Rexroth's books, lectures, and poetry readings.

Arranged in Subseries A-C as follows:
A. Lectures, 1953-1974 (2 boxes).
B. San Francisco State College, 1957-1966 (1 box).
C. UC Santa Barbara, 1968-1974 (6 boxes).

Correspondence and printed materials related to Rexroth's lecture dates and tours. The original contents of the files were preserved during processing, with the series arranged in an approximate chronological order.
Material related to Rexroth's lectures and workshops at the San Francisco State College Poetry Center, and four folders of student work.

did.unittitle: San Francisco State Poetry Center--Printed materials.
San Francisco State Poetry Center--Student work.
San Francisco State Poetry Center--Student work.

scopecontent.p: Administrative papers, memoranda and teaching files related to Rexroth's appointment in the English department at UCSB. The teaching files primarily include course evaluations and student work from English 183 and 100. The original contents of the files were preserved during processing, with the similar materials arranged in approximate chronological order. See box 120 for an oversize student poetry project from Winter, 1969.
Letters and memos regarding Rexroth's teaching appointments at UCSB.
Brochures on the UCSB Conference on Effective Teaching, University Vacation Center, and a Hustler's Handbook.
Student evaluations and course work. Arranged chronologically by academic quarter, where possible.
